awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Scalable Manufacturing of Hierarchical Nanostructures by Acoustically Modulated Emulsion Technique for Next Generation Renewable Energy Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Assembling nano building blocks into hierarchical structures can produce novel materials with unprecedented performance and functionalities, especially for next-generation renewable energy applications, including high-capacity batteries and high-efficiency solar cells, thus securing the energy future and prosperity of the nation. Existing methods to manufacture hierarchical nanostructures with long-range order require the use of templates that are limited in terms of fabrication scalability, cost, and time. They also lag behind on generating controlled composition variations in three-dimensional structures. This award supports fundamental research to produce needed knowledge for the study of a facile process to generate scalable and reconfigurable three-dimensional templates for the directed assembly of hierarchical nanostructures with rationally designed structure, topology, composition, and long-range order. This research promotes scientific understanding of the self-assembly process and provides strategies to direct the assembly by engineering the environment. Since assembly process is common in nature, e.g., living cells assemble into functional organs following a hierarchical order, knowledge from this research contributes to the understanding of life and life's engineering, which impacts the NSF Big Idea of 'Understanding the Rules of Life'. The multi-disciplinary research, involving acoustics, fluid dynamics, materials science and manufacturing, provides unique training and research opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. The project involves community college students, especially, those from under-represented minorities, in research and help achieve academic success in science and engineering.

The assembly of hierarchical nanostructures directed by acoustically-modulated emulsion can overcome several limitations existing assembly methods have, including disordered structures in long range, high cost, lengthy time, low scalability, and limited control of composition and anisotropy. However, fundamental scientific barriers are yet to be overcome to fully exploit the application potential of hierarchical nanostructures. This research is to fill the knowledge gap on the dynamics of nanoparticles and nanoparticle-loaded droplets in the Pickering emulsion system when subjected to a standing acoustic field. The project performs multi-scale molecular dynamics and finite element simulation, coupled with experimental validation, to investigate the dynamics of nanoparticles and emulsion droplets and delineate the effects of key process variables. Based on the fundamental studies, acoustically-modulated emulsion systems are designed and developed to manufacture a set of rationally designed metal oxide hierarchical nanostructures with structural, topological and compositional anisotropy in both nano- and micro- scales. Using titanium dioxide-based dye sensitized solar cell as a model device, the correlation of nano- and micro- scale structural and compositional anisotropy with the macroscale material properties and device performances are established.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The safety, performance, cost and durability of batteries and solar cells are greatly dependent on the three-dimensional (3D) structures of their electrodes. The goal of this project is to design 3D structured electrodes for next-generation renewable energy systems and to manufacture such designer electrodes in a controlled, repeatable, scalable and economical way.

To achieve this goal, PI creatively utilizes acoustic field as a non-contact tweeze to pick up electrode materials and place them at designated locations based on specific design of the 3D structures. Furthermore, the mixing and separation of two different fluids and the co-motion of electrode materials with one of the fluids were used innovatively as a second mechanism to control the electrodes structures.  These methods are proven to be effective at patterning an unbeatably wide range of electrode materials because they do not rely on specific electrical, chemical, magnetic, optical or thermal properties of the materials.  They do not require adding any “foreign” materials to structure the electrodes. They are also not subtractive manufacturing that leads to unnecessary material waste. Electrodes manufactured by the acoustic and phase separation-based methods have unique 3D structures that are impossible to be manufactured by other methods. These structures are proven to enhance the electrode’s mass transport, reaction kinetics and improve power, energy and durability.  The utility of these electrode manufacturing methods can contribute to enhance performance and extend the lifetime of various energy storage/conversion infrastructure, including lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, solid-state batteries, solar cells, fuel cells, etc. These next-generation energy infrastructures will make huge impacts on our daily lives and economy by increasing the driving range and charging speed of electric vehicles, by increasing the amount of electricity generated from renewable sources, by reducing the cost and downtime of these energy infrastructures, etc.

Results from this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through three published journal papers. Another two journal papers are currently under review. Research findings from this project have been incorporated into a graduate-level course on advanced manufacturing of polymer and polymer composites taught by the PI at Iowa State University.

This project provides a unique opportunity for graduate students to work at the intersection of multiple disciplines, including mechanical engineering, materials engineering and physical chemistry. In addition, students working on the battery application received extensive training and hands-on experience with battery research and development, which prepared them to work in this fast-growing industry. Supported by this project, graduate students traveled to professional conferences to showcase their research outcome and build professional networks which helped them land competitive internship positions at leading battery manufacturing company and government labs.

Supported by this project, the PI and students have developed two hands-on outreach activities for K-12 students. The first one is “Art and Science of Sound” which provides visualization of the standing acoustic wave using sand patterns to demonstrate concepts of sound and vibration. The second one is “Making Batteries using Kitchen Items”, which uses food and kitchen supplies to build a simple battery and demonstrates the fundamental working principles of chargeable and nonchargeable batteries. These hands-on activities were presented by PI Hu and PhD students multiple times during the annual Boone Family STEM Festival in Boone, IA, to K-9 students and their families to encourage them to pursue careers in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Shan Hu
